answer_html: \(\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{-5}{2} < -1\)As the value is less than -1, we see that the revenue will decrease.
answer_latex: $\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{-5}{2} < -1$As the value is less than -1, we see that the revenue will decrease.
hints_html:
Recall that the formula for the price-elasticity of demand is

\(\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{p\cdot q'(p)}{q(p)}\).

Remember to compare this value to -1 to determine if revenue will increase or decrease.
hints_latex:
Recall that the formula for the price-elasticity of demand is

$\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{p\cdot q'(p)}{q(p)}$.

Remember to compare this value to -1 to determine if revenue will
increase or decrease.
hints_raw:
Recall that the formula for the price-elasticity of demand is

<math> \displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{p\cdot q'(p)}{q(p)}</math>.

Remember to compare this value to -1 to determine if revenue will increase or decrease.
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
Using the hint and the first part, we have that

\(\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{4\cdot q'(4)}{q(4)} = \frac{4(-5/4)}{2} = \frac{-5}{2} < -1\)

As the value is less than -1, we see that the revenue will decrease.
sols_latex:
Using the hint and the first part, we have that

$\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{4\cdot q'(4)}{q(4)} = \frac{4(-5/4)}{2} = \frac{-5}{2} < -1$

As the value is less than -1, we see that the revenue will decrease.
sols_raw:
Using the hint and the first part, we have that

<math> \displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{4\cdot q'(4)}{q(4)} = \frac{4(-5/4)}{2} = \frac{-5}{2} < -1</math>

As the value is less than -1, we see that the revenue will decrease.
statement_html:
The demand equation for a certain product is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}q^2+p^{3/2}+2p=20\end{aligned}\]

where q is the number of units per hour the manufacturer can sell at a price of p dollars per unit.

If the price is raised slightly from \$4 dollars, will the revenue increase or decrease (use the elasticity of demand to do this)?
statement_latex:
The demand equation for a certain product is

\displaystyle{}q^2+p^{3/2}+2p=20
\end{align*}

where q is the number of units per hour the manufacturer can sell at a
price of p dollars per unit.

If the price is raised slightly from \textbackslash{}\$4 dollars, will
the revenue increase or decrease (use the elasticity of demand to do
this)?

:<math>
